item.dc:creator: @xx_c1ph3r_xx xx c1ph3r xx
item.description:
@xx_c1ph3r_xx wrote:

could make a directory with textfile for each player, records trades per line with the shit seperated by semicolons or sumtn, its really easy to read text files with php, ive made a browser based game without mysql backend run off textfiles.

edit: forgot 2 say why add semicolons, could explode the file based on line feeds, then explode each line at the semicolons to get a nice usable array of the trade

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @KO9 KO9
item.description:
@KO9 wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:6, topic:329204”][quote author=KO9 link=topic=425592.msg3125707#msg3125707 date=1266013939]
I designed the RSCA tradelogging system for RSCA about a year ago, here is the table design:

+--------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+
| Field  | Type         | Null | Key | Default | Extra |
+--------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+
| from   | varchar(255) | YES  | MUL | NULL    |       |
| from_ip| varchar(255) | YES  | MUL | NULL    |       |
| to     | varchar(255) | YES  | MUL | NULL    |       |
| to _ip | varchar(255) | YES  | MUL | NULL    |       |
| time   | int(10)      | YES  | MUL | NULL    |       |
| id     | int(10)      | YES  |     | NULL    |       |
| x      | int(10)      | YES  |     | NULL    |       |
| y      | int(10)      | YES  |     | NULL    |       |
| amount | int(10)      | YES  |     | NULL    |       |
| type   | int(5)       | YES  |     | NULL    |       |
+--------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+

[/quote]
Too much redundancy.
Use two tables, both with the primary key ‘trade_id’ or something similar.
In the first table have the rows from, from_ip, to, to_ip, time, x, and y (presuming x and y are the location ordinates that the player is standing at).
In the second table have the rows item_id and amount.

Not sure what you mean by ‘type’. If that’s indicative of whether the item transfer took place because of a stake or because of a trade then that belongs in the first table.

It may be further improved, I don’t know – this reply is a bit rushed. This approach involves far less redundancy though while also avoiding rather bad table design. :P[/quote]
But then you’ll have an one more entry than i currently have and one extra table. For instance, you’ll have the 1 entry in the first table for the trade id and then n entries in the other table for the items. Where as currently I just have the n entries. I currently have 7,597,133 entries in this table and i’ve never had a problem with it tbh. Type is indeed stake/drop/trade/shop, etc.

j a m m y:

Hmh, i just use the log system thats in RSCD already, so it prints it into a .txt file, i don’t need another table for it.

Have fun searching through that when you have >50,000 trades

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Why is it bad though? Where does it hold me back? It’s working perfectly and so on (for me anyway).

Redundancy is too prominent. What happens in a trade with one item? Simply put, you have x unnecessary rows.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“KO9, post:3, topic:329204”]I designed the RSCA tradelogging system for RSCA about a year ago, here is the table design:

+--------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | Extra | +--------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | from | varchar(255) | YES | MUL | NULL | | | from_ip| varchar(255) | YES | MUL | NULL | | | to | varchar(255) | YES | MUL | NULL | | | to _ip | varchar(255) | YES | MUL | NULL | | | time | int(10) | YES | MUL | NULL | | | id | int(10) | YES | | NULL | | | x | int(10) | YES | | NULL | | | y | int(10) | YES | | NULL | | | amount | int(10) | YES | | NULL | | | type | int(5) | YES | | NULL | | +--------+--------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ [/quote]
Too much redundancy.
Use two tables, both with the primary key ‘trade_id’ or something similar.
In the first table have the rows from, from_ip, to, to_ip, time, x, and y (presuming x and y are the location ordinates that the player is standing at).
In the second table have the rows item_id and amount.

Not sure what you mean by ‘type’. If that’s indicative of whether the item transfer took place because of a stake or because of a trade then that belongs in the first table.

It may be further improved, I don’t know – this reply is a bit rushed. This approach involves far less redundancy though while also avoiding rather bad table design.
